articles.headline: Gone in Minutes, Out for Hours: Outage Shakes Facebook
articles.snippet: When apps used by billions of people worldwide blinked out, lives were disrupted, businesses were cut off from customers — and some Facebook employees were locked out of their offices.
articles.abstract: When apps used by billions of people worldwide blinked out, lives were disrupted, businesses were cut off from customers — and some Facebook employees were locked out of their offices.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: Hollywood Crew Union Votes to Authorize Strike Against Studios
articles.snippet: The International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees is at loggerheads with companies like Netflix, Disney and Amazon over streaming pay and long workdays.
articles.abstract: The International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees is at loggerheads with companies like Netflix, Disney and Amazon over streaming pay and long workdays.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood moved closer to a production shutdown on Monday after one of the film and television industry’s lower-profile unions said that members had overwhelmingly voted to authorize a strike.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling

articles.headline: Venice, Overwhelmed by Tourists, Tries Tracking Them
articles.snippet: Can cellphone data and surveillance cameras help restore the city’s old-world charm, or just destroy what magic remains?
articles.abstract: Can cellphone data and surveillance cameras help restore the city’s old-world charm, or just destroy what magic remains?
articles.lead_paragraph: VENICE — As the pandemic chased away visitors, some Venetians allowed themselves to dream of a different city — one that belonged as much to them as to the tourists who crowd them out of their stone piazzas, cobblestone alleyways and even their apartments.

articles.headline: With Biden’s Agenda in the Balance, Lobbying Kicks Into High Gear
articles.snippet: Business interests are using ads and other efforts to cajole Democrats to change or kill a $3.5 trillion social policy bill.
articles.abstract: Business interests are using ads and other efforts to cajole Democrats to change or kill a $3.5 trillion social policy bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As centrist Democrats in Congress have worked to block or strip out major provisions of President Biden’s $3.5 trillion social safety net and climate plan, a string of online ads has popped up in their states and districts, lavishing praise on them.

articles.headline: Energy Prices Spike as Producers Worry Over Pandemic and Climate
articles.snippet: Even as more costly fuel poses political risks for President Biden, oil companies and OPEC are not eager to produce more because they worry prices will drop.
articles.abstract: Even as more costly fuel poses political risks for President Biden, oil companies and OPEC are not eager to produce more because they worry prices will drop.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Americans are spending a dollar more for a gallon of gasoline than they were a year ago. Natural gas prices have shot up more than 150 percent over the same time, threatening to raise prices of food, chemicals, plastic goods and heat this winter.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: As the U.S. Hurtles Toward a Debt Crisis, What Does McConnell Want?
articles.snippet: Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, has a long record of tying debt ceiling increases to policy demands. But this time, he has made none.
articles.abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, has a long record of tying debt ceiling increases to policy demands. But this time, he has made none.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In March 2006, as the government veered dangerously close to a default, Senator Mitch McConnell, the No. 2 Republican, let the Bush White House know he was two votes short of what he needed to raise the legal limit on federal borrowing.

articles.headline: The End of a ‘Gilded Age’: China Is Bringing Business to Heel
articles.snippet: Executives sit in jail, tech companies are being reined in and the biggest developer is teetering. It’s the beginning of a new era for China’s economy.
articles.abstract: Executives sit in jail, tech companies are being reined in and the biggest developer is teetering. It’s the beginning of a new era for China’s economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chinese tech companies are reeling from regulation. Nervous creditors are hoping for a bailout for China’s largest developer. Growing numbers of executives are going to jail. An entire industry is shutting down.

articles.headline: Fears of a ‘Bottleneck Recession’: How Shortages Are Hurting Germany
articles.snippet: Europe’s largest economy is particularly vulnerable to shortages of key parts and raw materials because of its dependence on exports.
articles.abstract: Europe’s largest economy is particularly vulnerable to shortages of key parts and raw materials because of its dependence on exports.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — In Germany, where one in four jobs depends on exports, the crisis gumming up the world’s supply chains is weighing heavily on the economy, which is Europe’s largest and a linchpin to global commerce.

articles.headline: Captured, Killed or Compromised: C.I.A. Admits to Losing Dozens of Informants
articles.snippet: Counterintelligence officials said in a top secret cable to all stations and bases around the world that too many of the people it recruits from other countries to spy for the U.S. are being lost.
articles.abstract: Counterintelligence officials said in a top secret cable to all stations and bases around the world that too many of the people it recruits from other countries to spy for the U.S. are being lost.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Top American counterintelligence officials warned every C.I.A. station and base around the world last week about troubling numbers of informants recruited from other countries to spy for the United States being captured or killed, people familiar with the matter said.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes and Adam Goldman
